project_metadata.paper_title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
project_metadata.research_context: This study investigates genetic contact and admixture between Copper Age farming societies in southeastern Europe and Eneolithic groups from the steppe zone, addressing a critical gap in understanding the period between ~4500 BC and 3300 BC that preceded the expansion of Yamnaya pastoralists.

evidence.description: Genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from eight distinct sites spanning ~5400 to 2400 BC
evidence.source_location: Abstract and Results
evidence.verbatim_quote: we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period

evidence.description: Samples enriched for 1.24 million SNPs with coverage ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs
evidence.source_location: Results
evidence.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×

evidence.description: 113 new radiocarbon dates obtained for individuals in the study
evidence.source_location: Results
evidence.verbatim_quote: We also report 113 new radiocarbon dates

evidence.description: PCA shows SEE CA individuals form tight cluster overlapping with Neolithic Anatolian individuals
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: the chronologically younger SEE CA individuals from the emblematic sites of Yunatsite (YUN), Varna (VAR), Pietrele (PIE) and the multiple burial from Tell Petko Karavelovo (PTK), form a tight cluster that also overlaps with published Neolithic individuals from Anatolia and SEE

evidence.description: Outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in SEE
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: outgroup f3 statistics suggest local genetic homogeneity throughout the CA in this region

evidence.description: PIE060 outlier shows ~35% Iron Gates HG or KO1 ancestry via qpAdm modelling
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling with qpAdm supports a two-way model (Fig. 3d) with SEE N (around 65%) and Iron Gates HG or KO1 (around 35%) as the best proxies

evidence.description: DATES analysis estimates admixture 16.3 ± 13.4 generations before PIE060's radiocarbon date
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using DATES to determine the time of admixture between SEE N and Iron Gates HG as a local HG ancestry, we obtained an admixture estimate of 16.3 ± 13.4 generations (Z = 1.213), which corresponds to around 81–832 years before the mean 14C date of PIE060

evidence.description: High Y-chromosomal diversity at SEE CA sites - 7 lineages among 29 males at Pietrele
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: With seven different main lineages among 29 males in Pietrele (I2a1, C1a, G2a, H2, T1a, J2a and R1b-V88), six among 15 males in Varna (I2a1, I2a2, G2a, T1a, E1b1 and R1b-V88) and four among six males at Yunatsite (C1a, G2a, H2, J2a), the Y-chromosomal diversity during the SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe

evidence.description: READ analysis detected only 3 first-degree and 2 second-degree relationships among SEE CA individuals
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: When testing for genetic relatedness in each of the SEE CA sites using READ, we detected only three first-degree and two second-degree relationships in total

evidence.description: IBD analysis found no between-site links up to fourth-fifth degree for CA sites
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found no evidence for between-site links up to the fourth to fifth degree and only two pairs of individuals (PIE003-VAR010 and YUN005-VAR030) shared at least two blocks greater than 20 cM indicative of a fifth to seventh degree relationship

evidence.description: hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness in CA individuals
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: analysis of the runs of homozygosity (ROH) per individual using hapROH indicates low levels of parental background relatedness suggesting relatively large effective population sizes

evidence.description: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals form genetic cline in PCA between Neolithic/SEE CA and Steppe Eneolithic
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Eneolithic individuals from Ukraine (Ukraine Eneolithic), dated from around 4500–3500 bc, associated with the Cernavodă I and Usatove cultures, form a genetic cline in PCA space (Fig. 1b) between Neolithic/SEE CA individuals and published Eneolithic steppe individuals from the North Caucasus and Khvalynsk

evidence.description: No correlation between PC2 position and radiocarbon dates for Ukraine Eneolithic individuals
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656)

evidence.description: Kartal individuals are genetically highly heterogeneous - Kartal A vs Kartal B distinct genetic profiles
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals from Kartal (around 4150–3400 bc), associated with the Cernavodă I culture, are genetically highly heterogeneous, with five individuals (Kartal A) forming a cline between 'Steppe Eneolithic'/'Steppe Maykop' individuals and Early Neolithic groups, while three other individuals (Kartal B) fall closer to the latter

evidence.description: f4 statistics show Ukraine Eneolithic excess affinity to all HG groups compared to Turkey_N
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: First, compared to Turkey_N, Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups, as indicated by significantly negative f4 statistics (|Z| ≥ 3)

evidence.description: qpAdm supports four-way admixture for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV (Turkey_N, EHG, CHG, WHG)
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using distal qpAdm modelling we find support for a four-way admixture of Turkey_N, EHG, CHG and WHG for KTL001, KTL007, MAJ and USV

evidence.description: KTL001 modelled as three-way mixture: ~32% Steppe Eneolithic, ~46% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, ~22% Ukraine N
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that KTL001 can indeed be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 32%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 46%) and Ukraine N foragers (around 22%), to the exclusion of a SEE CA source

evidence.description: MAJ and USV modelled as VAR_CA/Ukraine Trypillia (~50%), Steppe Eneolithic (~35%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (~15%)
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: MAJ and USV can be modelled as VAR_CA or Ukraine Trypillia (around 50%), Steppe Eneolithic (around 35%) and Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 15%) as minor third component

evidence.description: Rotating model approach strongly supports SEE CA contribution to most KTL individuals except KTL_B
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find strong support for a genetic contribution from SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop for most KTL individuals (except KTL_B), which can be modelled as Steppe Eneolithic and VAR_CA

evidence.description: IBD analysis found fourth-sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find a fourth to sixth degree relationship between MAJ023 and USV006, which reflects the close geographical vicinity of the two sites

evidence.description: ROH indicates elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV compared to CA
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: in comparison to the preceding CA and heterogenous KTL individuals, ROH indicate a slightly elevated parental background relatedness for MAJ and USV (Extended Data Fig. 5), suggesting smaller effective population sizes in Usatove-associated groups

evidence.description: Y-chromosomal lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic reflect lineages from contributing sources - G2a, I2a1, R1b
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Y-chromosomal evidence from the six Ukraine Eneolithic males reflects lineages from each of the contributing sources: G2a is probably a Neolithic legacy, while three males carrying I2a1 could be attributed to the local Ukrainian Neolithic or HG groups in general. KTL005 and MAJ009 carry haplotypes R1b/M343(×P297) and R1b1/L754(×M269), respectively

evidence.description: No R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages observed in Ukraine Eneolithic males
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Importantly, we do not observe R1b-Z2103 or immediate R1b-M269 precursor lineages, which originated in the steppe and are later linked with expansion of steppe-related ancestry

evidence.description: EBA individuals form two contrasting clusters - farmer-like and steppe ancestry clusters
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: The EBA individuals in this study are characterized by two contrasting clusters of genetic ancestry in PCA space (Fig. 1b) and different genetic affinities in outgroup f3 statistics

evidence.description: YUN_EBA and PIE078 males carry Y-chromosome lineage I2a (HG legacy), BOY/MAJ_EBA males carry R1b-Z2103
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: Intriguingly, the males from YUN_EBA/PIE078 carried Y-chromosome lineages I2a, suggestive of a HG legacy, while the males from BOY/MAJ_EBA carried R1b-Z2103 or derived lineages, a characteristic hallmark of Yamnaya-associated ancestry

evidence.description: f4 statistics confirm excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE vs CA
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: we tested for additional attraction towards HG-related groups in YUN_EBA and PIE078 compared to their CA predecessors by using f4(CA, EBA; HGs, Mbuti) and confirmed the excess HG ancestry in EBA individuals from YUN and PIE with significant negative results (|Z| ≤ 3)

evidence.description: YUN041 outlier has higher affinity to VAR_CA than other EBA groups
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: only the outlier individual YUN041 has a higher affinity to VAR_CA than to other EBA groups

evidence.description: BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara modelled as three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Ukraine N
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can be modelled as a three-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop and Ukraine N

evidence.description: Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya supports two-way model: ~65% Steppe Eneolithic and ~35% USV
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: For Ukraine_EBA_Yamnaya, we find support for a three-way model (P = 0.07) with Steppe Eneolithic (around 75%), Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop (around 14%) and Globular Amphora (around 11%) as a western source but also improved model fit (P = 0.5) for a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic (around 65%) and USV (around 35%)

evidence.description: Yamnaya Caucasus modelled as ~76% Steppe Eneolithic and ~26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: Yamnaya Caucasus individuals from the southern steppe can be modelled as a two-way model of around 76% Steppe Eneolithic and 26% Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop

evidence.description: BOY019 modelled as ~63% USV + ~37% Steppe Eneolithic or ~40% Ukraine Trypillia + ~60% Steppe Eneolithic
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individual BOY019 can be modelled successfully with around 63% USV and around 37% Steppe Eneolithic ancestry or around 40% Ukraine Trypillia and around 60% Steppe Eneolithic

evidence.description: YUN041 modelled as ~50% local YUN_EBA and ~50% BOY_EBA or Yamnaya source
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: individual YUN041 can be modelled as around 50% local YUN_EBA ancestry and 50% of either BOY_EBA or another Yamnaya-associated source

evidence.description: All f4 statistics non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3) when testing Yamnaya-associated individuals for homogeneity
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: with the exception of outlier individual Ukraine_Ozera_EBA_Yamnaya, all f4 statistics are non-significant (|Z| ≤ 3) (Supplementary Table W), which indicates that all Yamnaya-associated individuals including those from Ukraine and Bulgaria are genetically highly similar

evidence.description: Two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021) positive for Hepatitis B virus; VAR021 also positive for Salmonella enterica
evidence.source_location: Discussion
evidence.verbatim_quote: Despite the systematic screening of teeth, we found no evidence for pathogens among the CA individuals of the fifth and fourth millennium bc, apart from two individuals (YUN048 and VAR021), who were positive for the Hepatitis B virus (HBV), while individual VAR021 was also positive for Salmonella enterica

evidence.description: Sample processing: 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth processed total
evidence.source_location: Methods
evidence.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total

evidence.description: DNA damage patterns show fragment lengths 45-65 bp and deamination 6-17% (UDG-half) or 30-38% (non-UDG)
evidence.source_location: Methods - Ancient DNA authentication
evidence.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA, which includes short DNA fragment lengths (45–65 bp on average) and postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules (6–17% for partial UDG treatment, 30–38% for non-UDG treatment)

evidence.description: Contamination estimates: mitochondrial 0.086% to -9.2%, nuclear (males) 0.2% to 2%
evidence.source_location: Methods - Ancient DNA authentication
evidence.verbatim_quote: estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix (Supplementary Table A), ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%. The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%

evidence.description: PTK001 excluded due to ~18% contamination
evidence.source_location: Methods - Ancient DNA authentication
evidence.verbatim_quote: PTK001 yielded a contamination estimate of around 18% and therefore was excluded from all further analysis

evidence.description: DNA data deposited in European Nucleotide Archive under PRJEB62503
evidence.source_location: Data availability
evidence.verbatim_quote: The DNA sequences reported in this paper have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB62503

evidence.description: Cut-off of 400,000 SNPs used for hapROH and imputation; >550,000 SNPs for IBD analyses
evidence.source_location: Results
evidence.verbatim_quote: We used a cut-off of 400,000 SNPs for hapROH and imputation and filtered for >550,000 SNPs for identity-by-descent (IBD) analyses

evidence.description: Distal qpAdm modelling confirms minimal EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry in SEE CA, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: Distal qpAdm modelling (Fig. 3a and Supplementary Table G) confirmed minimal amounts of EHG-, CHG- and WHG-like ancestry, in addition to predominantly Turkey_N-like ancestry

evidence.description: PIE039 (earliest-dated individual) falls in expected range of SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: The earliest-dated individual in our dataset, PIE039 from Pietrele, falls in the expected range of other SEE Neolithic individuals in PCA space, with whom she also shares affinities according to outgroup f3 statistics

evidence.description: Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N found symmetrically related to PIE039 (|Z| ≤ 1)
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: We found Hungary_LN_Sopot and Malak Preslavets N to be most symmetrically related to PIE039 with respect to all HG comparisons (|Z| ≤ 1) and thus combined them into local group SEE 1, which could be used as a single source for proximal qpAdm modelling (P = 0.41)

evidence.description: All SEE CA groups modelled as single-source model using local Neolithic proxies
evidence.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using the respective, locally preceding, Neolithic groups for proximal qpAdm modelling, we could model all SEE CA groups as a single-source model (Fig. 3d and Supplementary Table H), suggesting genetic continuity at the local scale

evidence.description: Potential freshwater reservoir effect noted for some 14C dates from Steppe Eneolithic sites
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Some of the newly reported 14C dates could be affected by a freshwater reservoir effect, common in Steppe Eneolithic sites and could therefore be several centuries younger than their reported dates. However, accounting for this possibility, an offset of around 500 years would still date most of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals to the fourth millennium bc

evidence.description: Majaky and Usatove individuals are genetically more homogeneous than Kartal
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: The five contemporaneous individuals from Majaky (MAJ), are genetically more homogeneous and fall together with the four individuals from the late Eneolithic Usatove type-site (USV/UBK; Supplementary Table A) in the middle of the 'Kartal cline'

evidence.description: Re-analysis of Immel et al. data shows EHG-rich ancestry rather than Yamnaya ancestry in Cucuteni-Trypillia individuals
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: Such an early interaction has been postulated by Immel et al., who have reported Yamnaya-related ancestry in individuals associated with the Cucuteni–Trypillia complex from today's Moldova. However, on re-analysis of these data we find that this signal can be explained solely by an increase in especially EHG-rich ancestry

evidence.description: Sample breakdown: Neolithic (n=1), CA (n=95), Eneolithic (n=18), EBA (n=21)
evidence.source_location: Results
evidence.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21)

evidence.description: PCA constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 populations
evidence.source_location: Results
evidence.verbatim_quote: To assess the genetic ancestry and variation of the newly typed individuals we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

evidence.description: USV requires Maykop-associated ancestry (P=0.93 with four-way mixture including Maykop)
evidence.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
evidence.verbatim_quote: The same model is supported for MAJ (P = 0.05) but rejected for USV, which indicates that Maykop-associated ancestry is needed for the latter. Indeed, the competing model, with Maykop as an additional source and VAR_CA as an outgroup, results in a well-fit four-way mixture model for USV (P = 0.93)

evidence.description: All EBA show excess affinity to Turkey_N compared to Steppe Eneolithic (except Yamnaya Caucasus)
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: With the exception of Yamnaya Caucasus, all EBA individuals show an excess affinity to Turkey_N when compared to Steppe Eneolithic

evidence.description: Radiocarbon dating carried out at Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie using IntCal20 and OxCal v.4.4.2
evidence.source_location: Methods - Radiocarbon dating
evidence.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany... All samples were calibrated on the basis of the IntCal20 database and using OxCal v.4.4.2

evidence.description: 11 previously published 14C dates from Varna included
evidence.source_location: Methods - Radiocarbon dating
evidence.verbatim_quote: We also included 11 published, direct 14C dates for individuals from Varna

evidence.description: BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can also be modelled as two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic and KTL001
evidence.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age
evidence.verbatim_quote: we find that BOY_EBA, MAY_EBA and Yamnaya Samara can also be modelled as a two-way mixture of Steppe Eneolithic and KTL001 (who lacked SEE_CA ancestry)

evidence.description: IBD analysis quality thresholds: >0.5× coverage (~550,000 SNPs) for imputation inclusion, ancIBD v.0.4 with >600,000 SNPs and >0.99 genotype probabilities, blocks >220 SNPs/cM and >5 cM retained
evidence.source_location: Methods - Imputation and IBD sharing
evidence.verbatim_quote: Samples with more than 0.5× coverage on the 1,240,000 positions (around 550,000 SNPs) after imputation were included in IBD analysis... IBD sharing analysis was done using ancIBD (v.0.4) on individuals with more than 600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities > 0.99 after imputation with GLIMPSE... Following that, only shared blocks of more than 220 SNPs per centimorgan and shared blocks of more than 5 cM were kept for data quality purposes

consolidation_metadata.rationale: All three items describe IBD analysis quality parameters supporting same methodological claim

evidence.description: Samples imputed using GLIMPSE v.1.0.1 with 1000G panel as reference
evidence.source_location: Methods - Imputation
evidence.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters... We then determined genotype likelihoods from trimmed bam files using bcftools with the 1,000G panel... as a reference

evidence.description: HOPS pipeline used for pathogen screening with custom RefSeq database
evidence.source_location: Methods - Metagenomic pathogen screening
evidence.verbatim_quote: Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2). First, adaptor-clipped reads were mapped to a custom-made RefSeq database using MALT v.0.4.0

evidence.description: Permission to work on archaeological samples granted by excavators, archaeologists, curators and museum directors
evidence.source_location: Methods - Permission statement
evidence.verbatim_quote: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study

evidence.description: All 14C dates consistent with archaeological chronology based on stratigraphy and grave goods
evidence.source_location: Methods - Radiocarbon dating
evidence.verbatim_quote: All 14C dates in this study are consistent with the archaeological chronology based on stratigraphy and grave goods

evidence.description: DNA enrichment achieved 0.7× mean coverage for 1.24M SNP panel using 0.1% endogenous threshold
evidence.source_location: Methods - Ancient DNA laboratory procedures
evidence.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture (1,240,000 SNP capture)... Enriched libraries were sequenced on HiSeq4000 and NextSeq500 Illumina platforms using a single-read (SR 75) kit and sequencing 40 million reads for libraries between 0.1% and 2% or 20 million reads for libraries above 2%, resulting in a mean coverage of 0.7×

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items describe DNA enrichment lab procedures supporting same claim about data generation

evidence.description: Mitochondrial capture resulted in average coverage of 64×
evidence.source_location: Methods - Ancient DNA laboratory procedures
evidence.verbatim_quote: An additional mitochondrial capture was performed for individuals for which enough reads could not be obtained as by-catch of the 1,240,000 capture, resulting in an average coverage of 64×

evidence.description: YMCA capture resulted in mean coverage of 0.08× for Y chromosome
evidence.source_location: Methods - Ancient DNA laboratory procedures
evidence.verbatim_quote: For selected male individuals we also performed an inhouse capture assay for the Y chromosome (YMCA) which targets around 10.445 kB on the non-combining region of the Y chromosome and which resulted in a mean coverage of 0.08×

evidence.description: Three individuals from PIE identified as identical and merged; two pairs from YUN CA merged
evidence.source_location: Methods - Genetic relatedness analysis
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three individuals from PIE were identified as identical and were therefore merged for downstream analysis. Two pairs of the newly published samples from YUN CA had to be merged as they were revealed to be the same individuals

evidence.description: Individuals with <30,000 SNPs on HO-dataset excluded from PCA
evidence.source_location: Methods - Population genetic analysis
evidence.verbatim_quote: Individuals with fewer than 30,000 SNPs on the HO-dataset covered were excluded from the PCA

claims.claim_statement: The study successfully generated genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from eight sites spanning ~5400-2400 BC, achieving 0.7× mean coverage for the 1.24M SNP panel
claims.source_location: Abstract and Results
claims.limitations: 135 of 216 attempted individuals yielded sufficient data

consolidation_metadata.rationale: C53 technical coverage details absorbed into main data generation claim

claims.claim_statement: Genetic continuity exists between Neolithic and Copper Age groups from major sites in southeastern Europe
claims.source_location: Abstract

claims.claim_statement: From around 4500 BC, groups from the northwestern Black Sea region carried varying amounts of mixed ancestries derived from Copper Age groups and forest/steppe zones
claims.source_location: Abstract
claims.limitations: Some radiocarbon dates may be affected by freshwater reservoir effect

claims.claim_statement: 113 new radiocarbon dates were obtained and are consistent with archaeological chronology
claims.source_location: Results and Methods

claims.claim_statement: SEE CA individuals from Yunatsite, Varna, Pietrele and Petko Karavelovo form a tight genetic cluster
claims.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries

claims.claim_statement: Local genetic homogeneity was maintained throughout the Copper Age in southeastern Europe
claims.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries

claims.claim_statement: PIE060 is an outlier with ~35% HG ancestry from recent admixture, suggesting origin from a community with recent HG contact
claims.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
claims.limitations: DATES estimate has large uncertainty (16.3 ± 13.4 generations)

claims.claim_statement: Y-chromosomal diversity during SEE CA was higher than in central/western Europe
claims.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries

claims.claim_statement: Close genetic relatives were rare within SEE CA sites, with only 3 first-degree and 2 second-degree relationships detected
claims.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries

claims.claim_statement: No evidence for close genetic links between contemporaneous SEE CA sites up to fourth-fifth degree
claims.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries
claims.limitations: Limited by SNP coverage requirements for IBD

claims.claim_statement: SEE CA individuals had low parental background relatedness suggesting large effective population sizes
claims.source_location: Results - Neolithic and Copper Age ancestries

claims.claim_statement: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals form a genetic cline between SEE CA/Neolithic and Steppe Eneolithic groups
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: The observed genetic cline reflects admixture between CA farmer groups and Eneolithic steppe groups over ~1,000 years
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic
claims.limitations: Potential freshwater reservoir effect on some dates

claims.claim_statement: No correlation exists between genetic ancestry position and radiocarbon dates for Ukraine Eneolithic individuals
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Kartal individuals are genetically highly heterogeneous, representing the transformative dynamics of the fourth millennium BC
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Ukraine Eneolithic individuals show excess affinity to all HG groups compared to Anatolian farmers
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Distal ancestry modelling supports four-way admixture (Turkey_N, EHG, CHG, WHG) for key Ukraine Eneolithic individuals
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: KTL001 had distinct admixture history excluding SEE CA source, involving Steppe Eneolithic, Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop, and Ukraine N
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: MAJ and USV individuals show distinct three-way admixture including SEE CA farmer component
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Rotating model approach supports SEE CA rather than Caucasus Eneolithic/Maykop contribution to most Kartal individuals
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Close genetic relationship (4th-6th degree) between MAJ023 and USV006 reflects geographical proximity of sites
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Usatove-associated groups had smaller effective population sizes than preceding CA groups
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Y-chromosomal lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic males reflect contribution from multiple ancestral sources
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: Absence of R1b-Z2103 lineages in Ukraine Eneolithic indicates they predate Yamnaya expansion
claims.source_location: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

claims.claim_statement: EBA individuals form two contrasting genetic clusters - farmer-like and steppe ancestry
claims.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.claim_statement: Y-chromosome lineages clearly distinguish farmer-derived EBA groups (I2a) from Yamnaya-associated groups (R1b-Z2103)
claims.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.claim_statement: EBA individuals from YUN and PIE show excess HG ancestry compared to their CA predecessors
claims.source_location: Results - Genetic ancestries during the Bronze Age

claims.claim_statement: YUN041 is an outlier showing evidence of admixture between local farmer-like and incoming steppe groups

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The study assumes that genetic ancestry patterns can be used to infer population movements, contacts, and cultural interactions in prehistory
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Genetic ancestry reflects demographic and cultural processes
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Genetic data alone cannot distinguish between different social mechanisms of gene flow (migration, marriage networks, conquest, etc.)

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The use of 'cornerstone' populations (Turkey_N, WHG, EHG, CHG) as ancestry proxies assumes these represent discrete source populations
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Ancient reference populations adequately represent ancestral gene pools
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: These reference groups may themselves be admixed or not fully representative of actual ancestral populations

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The study assumes that the 135 successfully analysed individuals are representative of their respective archaeological cultures and time periods
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Burial practices may have been socially selective; preservation bias affects sample availability

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The correlation between genetic admixture and innovation transfer is assumed without direct evidence of specific technology transmission
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Genetic contact facilitated technological and cultural exchange
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Ideas and technologies can spread without genetic contact; correlation does not establish causation

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The study implicitly assumes that Y-chromosome lineage distributions reflect male-mediated gene flow patterns
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Sex-biased migration can be detected through uniparental marker patterns
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Y-chromosome patterns may reflect genetic drift in small populations rather than systematic sex-biased migration

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The qpAdm modelling approach assumes admixture occurred from discrete source populations at specific times
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Admixture can be modelled as pulse events from defined sources
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Continuous gene flow or complex admixture histories may not be well captured by discrete source models

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The absence of R1b-Z2103 in Ukraine Eneolithic is interpreted as evidence for pre-Yamnaya chronology
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: R1b-Z2103 is a reliable marker for Yamnaya expansion
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Small sample size of males (n=6) may miss rare lineages; lineage frequencies could vary regionally

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The study assumes that ROH patterns reliably indicate effective population sizes
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Runs of homozygosity reflect population demographic history
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: ROH can be affected by recent inbreeding events that don't reflect long-term population size

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The interpretation that CA settlement abandonment may have involved multiple factors (conflict, climate, disease) treats these as alternatives rather than potentially synergistic
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Causes of societal collapse can be distinguished
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Multiple interacting factors may be impossible to disentangle with available data

implicit_arguments.argument_description: The study assumes that the chronological framework based on radiocarbon dating is sufficiently precise to establish sequences of admixture events
implicit_arguments.underlying_assumption: Radiocarbon dating provides adequate temporal resolution
implicit_arguments.potential_challenges: Freshwater reservoir effects acknowledged; calibration uncertainties may obscure rapid demographic changes

research_designs.description: Multi-site, multi-period archaeogenomic study to address spatial and temporal sampling gap in understanding contact between late farming and pastoralist societies
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To address this question, we analysed genome-wide data from 135 ancient individuals from the contact zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region spanning this critical time period.
research_designs.rationale: Addresses poorly understood period between CA demise (~4250 BC) and pastoralist expansion (~3300 BC)
expected_information_missing: Explicit justification for site selection criteria

research_designs.description: Strategic sampling across eight distinct sites spanning ~5400 to 2400 BC to capture genetic variation across Neolithic, Copper Age, Eneolithic, and Early Bronze Age periods
research_designs.verbatim_quote: In total, we report genome-wide data for 135 (out of 216 attempted) individuals from eight distinct sites (Fig. 1) ranging from around 5400 to 2400 bc: Neolithic (n = 1), CA (n = 95), Eneolithic (n = 18) and EBA (n = 21).
research_designs.rationale: Captures key temporal transitions and contact zones between farming and pastoralist groups
expected_information_missing: Explicit sampling strategy for site selection

research_designs.description: Use of 'cornerstone' populations (Turkey_N, WHG, EHG, CHG) as ancestry proxies for formal admixture testing
research_designs.verbatim_quote: To formally characterize the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals, we tested for excess shared ancestry with four Holocene 'cornerstone' populations (Turkey_N, WHG, EHG/WSHG and CHG)

source_location.section: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

research_designs.rationale: Enables quantitative ancestry modelling using established reference populations

research_designs.description: Rotating sources to outgroups to distinguish between competing ancestry models
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Finally, to test whether we can distinguish between the farmer-related ancestry contributed by SEE CA- or Maykop-associated groups from the Caucasus, or by both, we rotated each source to the outgroups, alternatingly, keeping Steppe Eneolithic as a constant.

source_location.section: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

research_designs.rationale: Enables discrimination between competing ancestry sources that may otherwise be confounded

methods.description: 1.24 million SNP panel enrichment for genome-wide data generation from ancient skeletal remains
methods.verbatim_quote: All samples were enriched for a panel of 1.24 million single-nucleotide polymorphisms (1,240,000 SNP panel), ranging from 61,000 to 947,000 SNPs with an average SNP coverage between 0.01× and 3.4×.

methods.description: Accelerated mass spectrometry (AMS) radiocarbon dating for chronological control
methods.verbatim_quote: Radiocarbon dating was carried out using accelerated mass spectrometry at the Curt-Engelhorn-Zentrum Archäometrie gGmbH in Mannheim, Germany.

methods.description: PCA projection of ancient individuals onto modern West Eurasian genetic variation
methods.verbatim_quote: To assess the genetic ancestry and variation of the newly typed individuals we first performed principal component analysis (PCA) constructed from 1,253 modern-day West Eurasians from 77 different populations, onto which data from the ancient individuals were projected

methods.description: f3 and f4 statistics for measuring genetic relatedness and testing ancestry models
methods.verbatim_quote: Outgroup f3 statistics were calculated using qp3Pop to obtain the genetic relatedness of a target population to a set of ancient Eurasian populations since the divergence from an African outgroup. The f4 and f3 statistics were calculated using qpDstat and the f4mode: YES function.

methods.description: qpAdm modelling for ancestry proportion estimation using distal and proximal sources
methods.verbatim_quote: Ancestry modelling and ancestry proportion estimation on the 1,240,000 SNP dataset was performed using qpAdm in ADMIXTOOLS (v.5.1; ref. 4).

methods.description: DATES software for estimating timing of admixture events
methods.verbatim_quote: The software DATES (v.753) was used to estimate the time of the admixture events of ancient populations under the assumption that gene flow occurred as a single event and that the generation time is 28 years.

methods.description: Y-chromosome and mitochondrial DNA haplogroup assignment
methods.verbatim_quote: HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0; ref. 84) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup (Supplementary Table A). Y-chromosome haplogroups for all male individuals were assigned using the manual assignment method of Y-haplogroup calling as described in ref. 70

source_location.section: Methods - Assignment of uniparentally inherited haplogroups

methods.description: READ software for genetic relatedness estimation between individuals
methods.verbatim_quote: Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings. Background relatedness was estimated using the median value, across all sites per temporal group

methods.description: ancIBD for detecting shared IBD segments indicating genetic relationships
methods.verbatim_quote: IBD sharing analysis was done using ancIBD (v.0.4) on individuals with more than 600,000 SNPs and genotype probabilities > 0.99 after imputation with GLIMPSE.

methods.description: hapROH for analysing parental background relatedness
methods.verbatim_quote: The software package HapROH (v.0.64) was used to analyse ROH on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data. Only samples with more than 400,000 SNPs were included in the analysis to prevent potential false positives

methods.description: Spearman correlation test for PC2 position vs radiocarbon dates
methods.verbatim_quote: We tested for a correlation between positions of the Ukraine Eneolithic individuals in PC2 and their 14C dates and found none (Spearman's ρ = 0.113, P = 0.6656).

source_location.section: Results - Early contacts during the Eneolithic

expected_information_missing: Software used for correlation analysis not specified

methods.description: HOPS pipeline for metagenomic pathogen detection in shotgun data
methods.verbatim_quote: Shotgun sequencing data were screened for the presence of pathogen DNA with the screening pipeline HOPS (v.0.2).

methods.description: Sampling of petrous bones and teeth for ancient DNA extraction
methods.verbatim_quote: We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total. Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method and, for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out.

methods.description: Assessment of DNA damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA
methods.verbatim_quote: All libraries, except PTK001, yielded damage patterns characteristic of ancient DNA, which includes short DNA fragment lengths (45–65 bp on average) and postmortem deamination at the end of the molecules (6–17% for partial UDG treatment, 30–38% for non-UDG treatment).

methods.description: ContamMix and ANGSD for estimating mitochondrial and nuclear contamination
methods.verbatim_quote: We merged Shotgun, 1,240,000 and mitochondrial capture data for each individual, mapped this against the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence for the complete human mitochondrial genome (NC 012920.1) and estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix (Supplementary Table A), ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%. The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%.

methods.description: GLIMPSE imputation using 1000 Genomes reference panel
methods.verbatim_quote: Samples were imputed using GLIMPSE (v.1.0.1) with the default parameters.

methods.description: Targeted capture for mitochondrial genome sequencing
methods.verbatim_quote: An additional mitochondrial capture was performed for individuals for which enough reads could not be obtained as by-catch of the 1,240,000 capture, resulting in an average coverage of 64×.

methods.description: Criteria for selecting which of the 216 attempted individuals to include in final analysis (135 successful)
trigger_text: Together, a total of 135 individuals yielded sufficient genomic data for downstream analysis.
We processed 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth in total.
methods.inference_reasoning: The paper reports 216 individuals attempted with 135 successful, and mentions processing 168 petrous bones and 129 teeth (297 total samples from 216 individuals). The criteria for initial sample selection from available skeletal material and decision-making for which individuals to attempt are not documented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Initial archaeological sample selection criteria before DNA extraction attempts not specified
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot evaluate potential selection biases in which individuals were sampled from each site

expected_information_missing: Archaeological criteria for skeletal sample selection
Preservation quality assessment prior to sampling
Completeness of available skeletal populations at each site

methods.description: Protocol for identifying and merging data from identical individuals sampled multiple times
trigger_text: Three individuals from PIE were identified as identical and were therefore merged for downstream analysis.
Two pairs of the newly published samples from YUN CA had to be merged as they were revealed to be the same individuals.
methods.inference_reasoning: The paper states individuals were 'merged' but does not document the methodology for merging sequence data from multiple samples - whether reads were combined, how genotypes were called from merged data, or quality control for merged datasets.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Data merging procedure for identical individuals not specified
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot verify whether merging introduced biases or affected coverage statistics reported

protocols.description: Modified DNA extraction protocol from skeletal material
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA was extracted from all samples following a modified protocol refs. 63,64.
expected_information_missing: Specific modifications to protocol not detailed in main text

protocols.description: Double-stranded DNA library construction with UDG-half treatment
protocols.verbatim_quote: DNA double-stranded libraries were built using a partial uracil-DNA-glycosylase (UDG-half) treatment. For samples that did not meet the threshold for further analysis, we attempted to increase the DNA yield by using an automated protocol for producing single-stranded, non-UDG libraries. All libraries were double-indexed with a unique pair of indices.

protocols.description: Initial shotgun sequencing screening for human DNA content assessment
protocols.verbatim_quote: First, all indexed libraries were screened by means of shotgun sequencing of 5 million reads on an Illumina HiSeq4000 or NextSeq500 sequencing platform using a single end (1 × 75 base pair (bp) reads) kit, followed by an assessment of human DNA content and DNA damage profiles (initial quality criteria).

protocols.description: 1,240,000 SNP capture enrichment and sequencing protocol
protocols.verbatim_quote: Libraries above the threshold of 0.1% endogenous DNA were enriched for around 1.2 million SNPs in a targeted in-solution capture (1,240,000 SNP capture). Enriched libraries were sequenced on HiSeq4000 and NextSeq500 Illumina platforms using a single-read (SR 75) kit and sequencing 40 million reads for libraries between 0.1% and 2% or 20 million reads for libraries above 2%, resulting in a mean coverage of 0.7×

protocols.description: Radiocarbon date calibration using IntCal20 and OxCal
protocols.verbatim_quote: All samples were calibrated on the basis of the IntCal20 database and using OxCal v.4.4.2. All 14C dates in this study are consistent with the archaeological chronology based on stratigraphy and grave goods.

protocols.description: smartpca protocol for PCA projection of ancient individuals
protocols.verbatim_quote: Data on the HO panel (around 600,000 SNPs) were used for PCA using the program 'smartpca' v.16000 (EIGENSOFT). Principal components were computed for 1,253 present-day western Eurasians from 77 different populations (Supplementary Table B) on which ancient individuals were projected, using the options 'lsqproject: YES' and 'shrinkmode: YES'. Individuals with fewer than 30,000 SNPs on the HO-dataset covered were excluded from the PCA.

protocols.description: ADMIXTOOLS protocol for f3 and f4 statistics
protocols.verbatim_quote: The f3 and f4 statistics were calculated using the ADMIXTOOLS package. Standard errors were computed with the default block jackknife approach and 3 s.e. are reported and plotted.

protocols.description: qpAdm protocol with specified outgroup sets for ancestry modelling
protocols.verbatim_quote: The following groups were used as a basic set of outgroups for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG.SG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG. Depending on the time period, the outgroup set was adjusted according to the specific test.

protocols.description: DATES parameters for admixture date estimation
protocols.verbatim_quote: DATES measures the decay of ancestry covariance to infer the admixture time and estimates the variance of this admixture using a jackknife approach. The following parameters were used for every run: binsize 0.001; maxdis 1; qbin 10; lovalfit 0.45.

protocols.description: Uniparental marker haplogroup assignment: HaploGrep2 for mtDNA and manual assignment method for Y-chromosome haplogroups
protocols.verbatim_quote: HaploGrep2 (v.2.4.0; ref. 84) was used to assign each consensus sequence to a specific mitochondrial haplogroup. Y-chromosome haplogroups for all male individuals were assigned using the manual assignment method of Y-haplogroup calling.

source_location.section: Methods - Assignment of uniparentally inherited haplogroups

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both haplogroup protocols assessed together as comprehensive uniparental marker assignment

protocols.description: READ protocol for pairwise relatedness estimation
protocols.verbatim_quote: Genetic relatedness was estimated using READ, using default parameter settings. Background relatedness was estimated using the median value, across all sites per temporal group. From pairs of first-degree relatives, the individual with lower number of SNPs on the 1,240,000 target region was excluded from downstream analysis.

protocols.description: ancIBD protocol for IBD segment detection
protocols.verbatim_quote: We used HapBLOCK to perform the IBD sharing estimation. Imputed samples were merged, then the vcf_to_1240K_hdf command was used to convert the vcf files to the hdf5 format. The hapBLOCK_chroms command was used to perform the IBD sharing analysis for each chromosome at a time using the default parameters. Following that, only shared blocks of more than 220 SNPs per centimorgan and shared blocks of more than 5 cM were kept for data quality purposes

protocols.description: hapROH protocol for runs of homozygosity detection
protocols.verbatim_quote: The software package HapROH (v.0.64) was used to analyse ROH on pseudohaploid 1,240,000 SNP capture data. Only samples with more than 400,000 SNPs were included in the analysis to prevent potential false positives

protocols.description: HOPS/MALT protocol for pathogen detection
protocols.verbatim_quote: First, adaptor-clipped reads were mapped to a custom-made RefSeq database using MALT v.0.4.0 in BlastN mode and with semiglobal alignment type and default pipeline settings. The used database included all available complete bacterial and viral genomes as of 2017 in addition to selected eukaryotic pathogen genomes and the human reference sequence GRCh38. The results were filtered with a predefined list of pathogens of interest and possible candidates authenticated on the basis of edit distance distribution, ancient DNA damage pattern and read distribution along the reference genome.

protocols.description: Skeletal sampling protocols: minimally invasive petrous bone sampling and tooth pulp chamber sampling for ancient DNA extraction
protocols.verbatim_quote: Petrous bones were sampled with a minimal invasive method and, for the sampling of the teeth, the crown was separated from the root and the inner pulp chamber was drilled out.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both sampling protocols assessed together as comprehensive skeletal sampling approach

protocols.description: EAGER pipeline for ancient DNA sequence processing
protocols.verbatim_quote: After demultiplexing, EAGER v.1.92.56 was used to process raw ancient DNA sequence data. Raw reads were trimmed for Illumina adaptor sequences using AdapterRemoval v.2.3.0. Subsequently, reads were mapped to the human reference genome hs37d5 using BWA v.0.7.12 and duplicates were removed using DeDup v.0.12.1. To analyse characteristic DNA damage in the form of G to A and C to T substitutions, mapDamage v.2.0.9 was used.

protocols.description: DNA contamination estimation: ContamMix for mitochondrial contamination (both sexes) and ANGSD for nuclear contamination (males only)
protocols.verbatim_quote: We merged Shotgun, 1,240,000 and mitochondrial capture data for each individual, mapped this against the revised Cambridge Reference Sequence for the complete human mitochondrial genome (NC 012920.1) and estimated contamination for both sexes on the mitochondrium using ContamMix (Supplementary Table A), ranging from 0.086% to −9.2%. The nuclear contamination for males was estimated using ANGSD and ranged from 0.2% to 2%.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both contamination protocols assessed together as comprehensive contamination QC

protocols.description: GLIMPSE imputation protocol with 1000G reference
protocols.verbatim_quote: Briefly, bam files were trimmed 2 bp to remove ancient DNA damage. We then determined genotype likelihoods from trimmed bam files using bcftools with the 1,000G panel (The 1,000 Genomes Project consortium) as a reference. We used GLIMPSE_impute on genomic chunks of 2,000,000 bp with the buffer size of 200,000 bp to perform imputation. We then ligated the chunks using GLIMPSE_ligate and determined the most likely haplotypes using GLIMPSE_sample. Samples with more than 0.5× coverage on the 1,240,000 positions (around 550,000 SNPs) after imputation were included in IBD analysis. No MAF filtering was performed, since only 1,240,000 positions were retained after imputation.

protocols.description: Targeted mitochondrial DNA capture protocol
protocols.verbatim_quote: An additional mitochondrial capture was performed for individuals for which enough reads could not be obtained as by-catch of the 1,240,000 capture, resulting in an average coverage of 64×.

protocols.description: YMCA capture protocol for Y chromosome enrichment
protocols.verbatim_quote: For selected male individuals we also performed an inhouse capture assay for the Y chromosome (YMCA) which targets around 10.445 kB on the non-combining region of the Y chromosome and which resulted in a mean coverage of 0.08×

protocols.description: pileupCaller protocol for pseudohaploid genotype calling
protocols.verbatim_quote: The effect of postmortem DNA damage on genotyping was minimized by removing 2 bp from the 3′ and 5′ ends of reads from double-stranded UDG-half-treated libraries (n = 131) using the trimbam function included in bamUtils v.1.0.13. The resulting filtered bam files were genotyped with pileupCaller v.1.4.0.2 by randomly calling one allele per position considering the human genome as a pseudohaploid genome (–randomHaploid). Only for quality controls 10 bp were removed from the 3′ and the 5′ ends for non-UDG treated single-stranded libraries, whereas the untrimmed bam files were treated with the–singleStrandMode in pileupCaller for genotyping.

protocols.description: Sex estimation from X and Y chromosome coverage
protocols.verbatim_quote: We estimated the genetic sex by calculating the coverage on the X, Y and the autosomal chromosomes, for which the X and Y coverage is normalized by the autosomal coverage and the relative length of each sex chromosome

protocols.description: Rationale and criteria for selecting specific outgroup populations for qpAdm modelling
trigger_text: The following groups were used as a basic set of outgroups for distal modelling: Mbuti.DG, Turkey_Epipaleolithic, Iran_GanjDareh_N, Russia_MA1_HG, Russia_Kostenki14, Italy_North_Villabruna_HG.
Depending on the time period, the outgroup set was adjusted according to the specific test.
protocols.inference_reasoning: While the outgroup populations are listed, the paper does not document why these specific populations were chosen as outgroups, the theoretical basis for their suitability, or the criteria for adjusting outgroups for different tests.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Selection rationale for outgroup populations not documented
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot evaluate whether outgroup selection could bias ancestry estimates

protocols.description: Criteria for using HO vs 1240K reference panels for different analyses
trigger_text: Data on the HO panel (around 600,000 SNPs) were used for PCA using the program 'smartpca'
All other analyses were performed on the above merged dataset on the 1,240,000 SNP panel (around 1.24 million SNPs).
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper uses two reference panels (HO ~600K and 1240K ~1.24M SNPs) for different analyses but does not document why specific panels were chosen for specific analyses or the tradeoffs involved.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Rationale for reference panel selection per analysis type not documented
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot evaluate whether panel choice affected analytical outcomes

expected_information_missing: Justification for HO panel use in PCA

author_orcids.notes: No ORCIDs found in PDF text. Paper is from Nature 2023 which has ORCID policy - ORCIDs may exist in journal publisher metadata but not present in extracted PDF content.

pid_graph_summary.notes: Paper DOI and ENA accession number present. No author ORCIDs in PDF, no software DOIs, no sample IGSNs despite archaeogenomics focus.

funding.verbatim_text: This research was funded by the Max Planck Society
European Research Council under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement nos 771234-PALEoRIDER, W.H.)

data_availability.verbatim_statement: The DNA sequences reported in this paper have been deposited in the European Nucleotide Archive under the accession number PRJEB62503.

machine_actionability.rationale: ENA is a major INSDC repository with programmatic API access, standardised metadata, and persistent accession numbers. Data directly downloadable via FTP/Aspera.

code_availability.verbatim_statement: No code availability statement found. Methods section references established software packages (ADMIXTOOLS, EIGENSTRAT, GLIMPSE, hapROH, ancIBD, HOPS/MALT) with version numbers and citations but no custom analysis code repository.

machine_actionability.rationale: No custom code shared. Analysis relied on published software packages cited in Methods.

author_contributions.verbatim_statement: W.H., S.H., P.W.S. and J.K. designed the study. R.K., G.G.-R., C.S., M.A.S., G.U.N., A. Chohadzhiev, A.S., K.P., S.R., M.L., I.M., B.G., K. Boyadzhiev, Y.B., K. Beutler and I.B. provided materials and resources. S.P. performed laboratory experiments. S.P., A.B.R., G.G.-R., C.S., G.U.N. and A. Childebayeva analysed the data. W.H., I.M., S.H., P.W.S., Y.B. and K. Boyadzhiev assisted with data interpretation. S.P., S.H., P.W.S., I.M., A.B.R. and W.H. wrote the manuscript with contributions from all co-authors.
author_contributions.notes: Full author list contains 30 authors. Contributions statement covers roles in study design, materials provision, laboratory work, data analysis, interpretation, and writing.

conflicts_of_interest.verbatim_statement: The authors declare no competing interests.

ethics_approval.notes: No formal ethics committee approval statement. Ancient DNA research on archaeological materials - see institutional permissions below.

permits.authority: excavators, archaeologists, curators, museum directors (as co-authors)
permits.verbatim_statement: Permission to work on the archaeological samples was granted by the respective excavators, archaeologist and curators and museum directors of the sites, who are co-authoring the study.

care_principles.notes: Archaeological materials from European sites. No Indigenous consultation or CARE principles documentation required for this regional context.

preregistration.notes: No preregistration - typical for archaeogenomics studies which are exploratory/descriptive rather than hypothesis-driven clinical research.

supplementary_materials.description: Supplementary Information containing detailed methods, supplementary tables A-Y (genotype data, f-statistics, qpAdm models, IBD analysis, ROH analysis, pathogen screening), Extended Data Figures 1-9, and Peer Review file

files.description: Supplementary Tables A-Y covering all genetic analyses

supplementary_materials.notes: Extensive supplementary materials typical of Nature publications. Access via publisher supplementary information tab.

references_completeness.notes: Most journal article references include DOIs or clear identifiers. References 1-94 with majority having DOIs in standard format.

f1_globally_unique_pid.rationale: ENA accession PRJEB62503 is globally unique persistent identifier

f2_rich_metadata.rationale: ENA requires structured metadata including sample information, sequencing parameters, and study description

f3_metadata_includes_pid.rationale: ENA metadata includes accession numbers linking to data files

f4_indexed_searchable.rationale: ENA is indexed in INSDC, Crossref, Europe PMC, searchable via EBI search

a1_retrievable_standard_protocol.rationale: Data retrievable via HTTP/FTP/Aspera standard protocols

a1_1_protocol_open_free.rationale: ENA uses open protocols, no authentication required for data access

a1_2_authentication_if_needed.rationale: N/A - data openly accessible without restrictions

a2_metadata_accessible_beyond_data.rationale: ENA metadata persists even if specific data files removed

i1_formal_knowledge_representation.rationale: BAM/CRAM sequence files use standardised formats; VCF for variants

i2_fair_vocabularies.rationale: Uses INSDC controlled vocabularies for organism, tissue, sequencing platform

i3_qualified_references.rationale: Cross-references to BioSamples, taxonomy databases, publications

r1_plurality_of_attributes.rationale: Rich metadata including sample provenance, sequencing methods, quality metrics

r1_1_clear_licence.rationale: No explicit data licence stated in paper; ENA default is open but licence not specified

r1_2_detailed_provenance.rationale: Full provenance: site, individual, sample, extraction, sequencing, processing

r1_3_community_standards.rationale: Follows INSDC standards for ancient DNA data submission

machine_actionability.rationale: ENA provides RESTful API, FTP access, programmatic download via Aspera. Sequence data in machine-readable formats (BAM/CRAM/FASTQ). Metadata queryable via ENA portal API.

discipline_context.context_rationale: As a 2023 Nature publication in genomics, high FAIR standards expected and achieved. ENA is the gold-standard repository for European sequence data. Only gap is explicit data licence statement.
discipline_context.baseline_comparison: Exceeds typical HASS baseline significantly; meets genomics community standards

recommendations: Add explicit data licence (CC0, CC-BY, or ODbL) to improve R1.1 compliance
Consider depositing analysis code to repository like Zenodo for computational reproducibility
Add author ORCIDs to PDF to improve PID connectivity

extraction_notes: ORCIDs not present in PDF text despite Nature ORCID policy - may be in publisher metadata only
No formal ethics committee approval - standard for European archaeogenomics using institutional permissions
No code repository despite complex computational analyses - relies on published software packages
Comprehensive funding disclosure with 5 distinct funding sources including ERC grants

consolidation_details: E62+E63 merged into E62 (lab procedure DNA enrichment details)
E55+E57+E58 merged into E55 (IBD analysis quality thresholds)
C01 absorbed C53 technical details (DNA coverage)
C04 retained separate from C52 (data generation vs validation - distinct purposes)
pass2_rationalization.notes: Minimal consolidation appropriate for this empirical genomics paper - most evidence items serve distinct analytical purposes supporting different claims. High granularity preserved for RDMAP extraction in subsequent passes.

pass1b_implicit_scan.scan_methodology: Systematic 4-pattern scan for implicit RDMAP: (1) Mentioned procedures without description, (2) Effects implying undocumented causes, (3) Tools without specifications, (4) Strategic positioning without explicit statement. This is an exceptionally well-documented paper with comprehensive Methods section covering most procedures with specific parameters and software versions.
pass1b_implicit_scan.findings: Minimal implicit RDMAP (8%) reflects exceptional methodological documentation typical of high-impact archaeogenomics papers. Identified gaps relate to sample selection criteria, data merging procedures, and analytical rationale rather than missing procedural documentation.

pass2_rdmap_rationalization.notes: Minimal consolidation appropriate for this well-structured archaeogenomics paper. Most RDMAP items represent distinct analytical procedures documented with specific parameters. The 6% reduction reflects the high granularity typical of population genetics papers where each statistical method serves a specific analytical purpose. Implicit items retained as they identify genuine transparency gaps.

bidirectional_validator.status: Corrections applied; conflicts are expected evidence-to-multiple-claims patterns

cross_reference_integrity.notes: All referenced IDs exist. 103 bidirectional mappings auto-corrected. 14 conflicts are valid many-to-many evidence-claim relationships.

hierarchy_validation.rdmap_chains: Valid - all methods connected to designs, all protocols connected to methods

source_verification.notes: All explicit items have verbatim_quotes; all implicit items have trigger_text and inference_reasoning

gaps_summary: No code repository despite complex analyses

recommendations: 14 evidence-claim conflicts are valid many-to-many relationships; no action needed
Consider explicit documentation of sample selection criteria for future papers
Consider publishing analysis code to repository
